title: Wexner Score for Obstructed Defecation Syndrome (ODS)
description: Stratifies severity of fecal incontinence in patients with obstructed defecation syndrome. Also known as the Cleveland Clinic Fecal Incontinence Score (CCFIS), this validated scoring system evaluates five key aspects of fecal incontinence to provide objective assessment of symptom severity and impact on quality of life.

parameters.name: incontinence_solid_stool
parameters.description: Frequency of incontinence to solid stool

parameters.name: incontinence_liquid_stool
parameters.description: Frequency of incontinence to liquid stool

parameters.name: lifestyle_alteration
parameters.description: Extent to which incontinence alters the patient's lifestyle

result.name: wexner_score
result.description: Wexner Score for fecal incontinence severity

ranges.interpretation: Wexner score of 0 indicates perfect continence with no fecal incontinence symptoms. No treatment is typically required. Continue routine care and lifestyle modifications as appropriate for underlying conditions.

Wexner score of 1-9 indicates mild fecal incontinence that may have minimal impact on quality of life. Consider conservative management including dietary modifications, fiber supplementation, pelvic floor exercises, and bowel training programs. Monitor symptoms and reassess regularly.

Wexner score â‰¥10 indicates clinically significant fecal incontinence requiring active management. Consider comprehensive evaluation including anorectal physiology testing, imaging studies, and specialist referral. Treatment options may include advanced conservative therapies, biofeedback, sacral nerve stimulation, or surgical interventions depending on underlying etiology.

formula: Sum of scores for: Incontinence to solid stool (0-4) + Incontinence to liquid stool (0-4) + Incontinence to gas (0-4) + Wears pad (0-4) + Lifestyle alteration (0-4). Each parameter scored: 0=Never, 1=Less than once a month, 2=Less than once a week but at least once a month, 3=Less than once a day but at least once a week, 4=At least once a day.
notes: Also known as Cleveland Clinic Fecal Incontinence Score (CCFIS)
Score ranges from 0 (perfect continence) to 20 (complete incontinence)
Most widely used and validated fecal incontinence scoring system
Correlates well with patient-reported symptom severity and quality of life impact
Does not account for fecal urgency, which may be assessed separately
Easily understood and completed by patients
Useful for monitoring treatment response and disease progression
Each parameter uses same 5-point frequency scale (0-4 points)
Lifestyle alteration refers to the extent incontinence impacts daily activities
Protective pad use frequency reflects practical management impact
Should be used in conjunction with clinical history and physical examination
May be repeated at follow-up visits to assess treatment effectiveness
